Brauer-Wall spaces and algebraic K-theory

Feb 3, 2020

I’m gonna force myself to write more often. I was working on a really interesting project this past month with a grad student in the physics department: we’re trying to understand anomaly cancellations via index theorems. I’ll write more in the next post (I hope), but roughly speaking, the parity anomaly for massless fermions (in odd dimensions) which are invariant under time-reversal can be cancelled by extending to a bulk of one dimension higher, and adding on “gravitational terms” (i.e., characteristic classes like the A-hat genus) — the cancellation stems from the Atiyah-Patodi-Singer index theorem on manifolds with boundary. It’s super cool stuff.

But for now, I’d like to talk about something that’s been lying dormant for a while. Recently, I found this answer of Charles Rezk, which basically talks about the idea of this post which I had tried to work on last semester. That’s what motivated me to write up this post.

Let be an -ring, and consider the Brauer space of . This is the Picard space of the -category of stable -linear -categories. If denotes the algebraic K-theory of , then there is a functor given by taking algebraic K-theory. The algebraic K-theory of a stable -linear -category is a -module because algebraic K-theory is lax symmetric monoidal. This also means that the functor is lax monoidal, and hence one can take Picard spaces to obtain an infinite loop map .

If is the complex numbers, then this defines a map . The source is easy to identify: as infinite loop spaces, where is given the discrete topology. This stems from the fact that the Brauer and Picard groups of are trivial.

There is a canonical -ring map , which Gabber-Suslin proved to be an equivalence upon -completion for any prime . One might therefore be interested in studying the Picard space — this is useful for a number of reasons, including studying -maps into . One may explicitly identify as an infinite loop space. We know that , and (i.e., with its H-space structure given by tensor product) decomposes as a product . The equivalence is a consequence of the tom Dieck/Rezk logarithm, and is also a consequence of work of Adams and Priddy on unique deloopings of infinite loop spaces. In any case, one finds that , and this gives

Again, this is an equivalence of infinite loop spaces.

In particular, the coconnected cover splits off . It can be explicitly identified with a certain moduli problem. Namely, if is an -ring, we can consider the -category of -graded -linear stable -categories. The Brauer-Wall space of is defined to be . Then there is an equivalence of infinite loop spaces

Similarly, .

There are a few ways one can prove this fact. Before I do so, I’m obligated to make a couple of comments. The homotopy groups of are

This is exactly the homotopy of , where is the Anderson dualizing spectrum. In fact, . Moreover, unpublished work of Hopkins and Lurie identifies with the fiber of the map , at least after -completion. One way to interpret the map is via this overblown construction.

The above identification of is originally (albeit not in this form) due to Atiyah, Bott, and Shapiro. There is a map , and the diagram

commutes. One might wonder if there is a moduli-theoretic description of the bottom map, since we gave a description of the top map in terms of algebraic K-theory. Here’s one way to do it.

The motivation comes from Atiyah-Bott-Shapiro’s original construction. Let’s recall how that goes: let denote the complex Clifford algebra associated to the negative-definite quadratic form over . This is a -graded algebra. Given any -graded -module , one can consider the constant vector bundles on , which we will think of as the unit ball in . One obtains a map , given over every point in by multiplication by that vector. Since the map is an isomorphism on the boundary (because the norm squared of a point on the boundary is ), one obtains an element of .

Now, if the -module structure on extends to a -module structure, then the isomorphism extends to the “upper hemisphere” of (which is a ). It follows that is an isomorphism on itself, so the resulting element of is trivial. In particular, we obtain a map

and Atiyah-Bott-Shapiro show that this map is an isomorphism.

So, the question becomes: how do you characterize ? More precisely, how do you characterize the image of in ? This isn’t so bad, based off the above discussion: a comes from a graded -module if there is an endomorphism (given by the action of ) such that , which is an element of the -vector space , is actually just a negative real (because the negative norm-squared of any nonzero complex number is a negative real). In particular, if we say that such a module is “extendible”, then we obtain a map from the Grothendieck group of modulo extendible objects to which is an isomorphism.

The advantage of this definition is that it doesn’t use any explicit description of Clifford algebras: if is a -graded -linear stable -category, then we can still say that a -graded object is extendible if there is an endomorphism such that is multiplication by a negative real. Let denote the quotient of by the extendible objects. Then is another -graded -linear stable -category, and we can take for some fixed prime . This defines a lax monoidal functor

However, , and by Gabber-Suslin, (as -rings), so the procedure defined above gives a lax monoidal functor

Taking Picard spaces, we obtain a map . This is the map we wanted to construct (upon composition with the map ).

What’s the point of doing it this way? Well, once we do non-formal work to identify the invertible objects in with for varying (in fact, all that matters in the complex case is , and in the real case), we find that the Atiyah-Bott-Shapiro identification of with (they do less than this, but the statement is still true) says that the map is an isomorphism. This is a priori not obvious at all: it says that the Brauer group grading agrees with the Picard group grading, and is Bott periodicity. All the stuff I said above goes through with the real numbers instead of .

One advantage of doing things in this way is that it suggests how one could go about generalizing it to algebraic K-theory. At this point, we hit an important roadblock. The reason -gradings on our categories played so well is because there is an isomorphism ; hence the simple definition of extendible objects. I’m not sure of the right way to define extendible objects in general -graded -linear stable -categories. Such a notion would allow us to define a lax monoidal functor

for every prime , and upon taking Picard spaces produce a map

I promised to tell you how to identify . Let’s first identify the homotopy groups of this space. We know that if is any ring, then is the Brauer-Wall group of (if or , this is the group of Clifford algebras modulo Morita equivalences, i.e., or ). Next, is the Picard group of . If , then there are exactly two invertible -graded -vector spaces: in degrees and , respectively. (Recall that the tensor product of and is in degree and , respectively.) If we were working in the ordinary categorical setting (so mapping spaces had discrete topologies), then would be . However, since is defined higher categorically, this is not true; rather, if denotes the “discrete” Brauer-Wall space, then there is a fiber sequence of spaces

where has the discrete topology. The long exact sequence on homotopy gives

so and .

Now consider the map . The fiber sequence involving and shows that this map factors through . We know that (because they’re both just ). To identify , we can induct up the Postnikov tower. Note that both and have both and given by , and no other homotopy. Any such space sits in a fiber sequence involving and — but it is easy to see that the only spaces which could possibly sit in such a fiber sequence are the point and . Since our spaces have nontrivial homotopy, they must both be the latter.

Neither nor have nontrivial , and both have given by . Therefore, if we write to denote either of these spaces, then there’s a fiber sequence

Since everything involved is an infinite loop space, to show that this fiber sequence splits, it suffices to construct a map . This is equivalent to a map . We know that this map already exists for : it’s the delooping of the inclusion

composed with the canonical map . Similarly, we know that , and so we obtain a map . There is a fiber sequence

for any symmetric monoidal -category , so we obtain our desired splitting map .
